thread.title: Amjyot makes the star turn again as India survive Hong Kong scare
thread.title_full: Amjyot makes the star turn again as India survive Hong Kong scare - The Times of India

author: Amit Sampat
title: Amjyot makes the star turn again as India survive Hong Kong scare
text:
NAGPUR: For the second successive game Amjyot Singh stamped his class as India rallied splendidly to survive Hong Kong scare in round 2 of the 28th Fiba Asia Basketball Championship at Changsha Hunan, China, on Monday. It was in the crucial last quarter that India turned the match on its head as they secured a 76-71 win.
The 6-foot-7 inform Indian forward scored 11 of his game-high 26 points as India reeled in seven unanswered points in the final 10 minutes to snatch victory from the jaws of defeat.
A day after their thrilling three-point win over giantkillers Palestine, a weary looking Indian outfit had a slow start. Having lost the first quarter 14-19, both the teams netted 20 identical points in the second period as Hong Kong took a handy five-point lead at the breather.
After the much needed break, India did manage to win the third period 19-17 but were trailing by three points in the end. With seven minutes remaining for the final hooter, Indian cagers' aggressive play helped them record a 16-7 run to seal the fate of the game by dominating the last period 23-15.
With yet another double-double - scoring 26 points and 12 rebounds - Amjyot did the star turn again in India's back-to-back second round win. Veteran Indian guard Yadwinder Singh, who usually keeps his focus on the defense, made his presence felt in the front court with a pivotal role of 18 points and six rebounds. With 16 points and six assists skipper Vishesh Bhriguvanshi continued his impressive play while Indian center Amrit Pal Singh did all the jumping. Amrit pulled as many as 14 rebounds and joined point guard Akilan Pari with identical 8 points.
Making most of the size, India outrebounded Hong Kong 47-42 and also had more points in the paint, 30-24.
A bit relaxed with the win, Amjyot told TOI, "It was a tough outing but we all made it." On the slow start, he added, "We were not at all casual in our approach, in fact we were a bit tired."
Skipper Vishesh added, "We never expected that our game against Hong Kong will go this much tough. Anyhow, we won an important game and it's great."
Confidence was the key for Yadwinder and team. "Though we were trailing for most part of the game, we all were fully confident that we would win," said Yadwinder and elaborated on his valuable contribution, "My focus has always been on defense but looking at the scoring that was stuck, I stepped up my aggression and it paid off."
In their last second round outing, India will face the challenge of world No 31 Philippines, who will be high on confidence after surprising defending champions Iran 87-73. After their second successive victory, India have a good chance of making it to the quarterfinals even if they lose to Philippines.
